metadata.title: Electrochemical performance and structure evolution of core-shell nano-ring α-Fe2O3@Carbon anodes for lithium-ion batteries

E n
Y S C
a
A R R A A
K A L C N
1
a e y s m t t o a c a o t a l
h 0
Applied Surface Science 390 (2016) 175–184
Contents lists available at ScienceDirect
Applied Surface Science
journa l homepage: www.e lsev ier .com/ locate /apsusc
lectrochemical performance and structure evolution of core-shell ano-ring -Fe2O3@Carbon anodes for lithium-ion batteries
an-Hui Sun ∗, Shan Liu, Feng-Chen Zhou, Jun-Min Nan chool of Chemistry and Environment, South China Normal University; Guangzhou Key Laboratory of Materials for Energy Conversion and Storage, South hina Normal University, Guangzhou, 510006, PR China
r t i c l e i n f o
rticle history: eceived 27 April 2016 eceived in revised form 22 July 2016 ccepted 15 August 2016 vailable online 17 August 2016
eywords: -Fe2O3 node ithium ion battery ore-shell structure ano-ring
a b s t r a c t
Core-shell nano-ring -Fe2O3@Carbon (CSNR) composites with different carbon content (CSNR-5%C and CSNR-13%C) are synthesized using a hydrothermal method by controlling different amounts of glucose and -Fe2O3 nano-rings with further annealing. The CSNR electrodes exhibit much improved specific capacity, cycling stability and rate capability compared with that of bare nano-ring -Fe2O3 (BNR), which is attributed to the core-shell nano-ring structure of CSNR. The carbon shell in the inner and outer surface of CSNR composite can increase electron conductivity of the electrode and inhibit the volume change of -Fe2O3 during discharge/charge processes, and the nano-ring structure of CSNR can buffer the volume change too. The CSNR-5%C electrode shows super high initial discharge/charge capacities of 1570/1220 mAh g−1 and retains 920/897 mAh g−1 after 200 cycles at 500 mA g−1 (0.5C). Even at 2000 mA g−1 (2C), the electrode delivers the initial capacities of 1400/900 mAh g−1, and still maintains 630/610 mAh g−1 after 200 cycles. The core-shell nano-rings opened during cycling and rebuilt a new flower-like structure consisting of -Fe2O3@Carbon nano-sheets. The space among the nano-sheet networks can further buffer the volume expansion of -Fe2O3 and facilitate the transportation of electrons and Li+ ions during the charge/discharge processes, which increases the capacity and rate capability of the electrode. It is the first time that the evolution of core-shell -Fe2O3@Carbon changing to flower-like networks during lithiation/de-lithiation has been reported.
. Introduction
Rechargeable lithium-ion batteries (LIBs) have been widely used s power sources of different electronic devices due to their high nergy density and long cycling life [1,2]. During the past few ears, the electrochemically active transition metal oxides such as ingle metal oxides Fe2O3, Fe3O4, TiO2, CuO, and Co3O4 [3], and ixed transition-metal oxides including stannates, ferrites, cobalates, and nickelates, have been exploited as anode materials for heir high theoretical capacity and natural abundance [4,5]. Among f them, transition metal oxide Fe2O3 has attracted considerable ttention because of its high theoretical capacity (1007 mAh g−1) ompared to graphite (372 mAh g−1), non-toxicity and natural bundance [3]. In contrast to graphite, the lithium storage of iron xides is mainly achieved through the reversible conversion reacion between lithium ions and metal nanocrystals dispersed in
Li2O matrix (Fe2O3 + 6Li+ + 6e ↔ 2Fe + 3Li2O, corresponds to the ithiation/delithiation of 6 mol Li+) [6–8]. Such a process usually
∗ Corresponding author. E-mail address: sunyanhui0102@163.com (Y.-H. Sun).
ttp://dx.doi.org/10.1016/j.apsusc.2016.08.071 169-4332/© 2016 Elsevier B.V. All rights reserved.
© 2016 Elsevier B.V. All rights reserved.
causes drastic volume variation (>200%) and severe destruction of the anode during the charging/discharging process, especially at a high rate; and the Fe2O3 usually shows poor electrical conductivity; both of them greatly affect the cycling stability and rate capability [6,7]. Therefore, tremendous efforts have been made to circumvent the above issues. One way is to design Fe2O3 with different morphologies [6–17] including nanorods [9,13], nano-fibers [10], hollow spheres [11,12], multi-shelled hollow spheres [13,14], nanotubes [8,15,16], nano-rings [8] and mesoporous [17], in which hollow structural materials can enhance the electrochemical performance by the hollow structure minimizing the severe volume change of Fe2O3 during lithium ion insertion and de-insertion. The other approach is to introduce carbonaceous materials into Fe2O3 anodes to improve their cycling stability by good conductivity and stable performance of carbonaceous materials [18–27]. For example, a novel Fe2O3 nanorods/carbon nanofiber composite exhibited superior discharge capacities, that is, 1278 mAh g−1 of the first cycle and 960 mAh g−1 of the 30th cycle at 200 mA g−1, which
−1
are much higher than that of 1069 mAh g of the first cycle and 560 mAh g−1 of the 30th cycle at 200 mA g−1 of the bare nanorods [20]; Li et al. reported that Fe2O3 nanoparticles/C nanocomposites exhibited reversible capacities of 470 and 419 mAh g−1 at

sections.text:
he 80th and 200th cycles with a current density of 125 mA g−1, hich are much higher than those of counterparts without carbon i.e., Fe2O3 nano-particles) [21]. Thus the assembly of novel Fe2O3 tructures and coating carbonaceous shell to improve the electrohemical performance of Fe2O3 anode is still a great challenge. ecently, Liu reported that nano-ring Fe2O3 anode presents better ithium-storage performance than the counterpart (nano-disk), the apacities are 861 mAh g−1 of Fe2O3 nano-rings and 683 mAh g−1 f Fe2O3 nano-disks cycled at 1000 mA g−1 after 100 cycles; and 47 mAh g−1 of Fe2O3 nano-ring and 157 mAh g−1 of nano-disk ycled at 10 A g−1 after 1000 cycles [8]. The results indicated the dvantages of the nano-ring structure Fe2O3 as anode materials f LIBs. Up to now, there are few reports on the lithium-storage erformance of Fe2O3 nano-ring structure [8] and their carbonaeous composites [24,25]. Li et al. reported a core-shell nanno-ring -Fe2O3@C as anode of LIB, but the core-shell nano-rings didn’t xhibit obvious improvement in cyclability than that of bare - e2O3 nano-rings, the capacity keeps 815 mAh g−1 at 1000 mA g−1 fter 160 cycles of core-shell nano-rings and 810 mAh g−1 at 000 mA g−1 after 30 cycles of the bare Fe2O3 nano-rings (no data or long cycle life) [24]. In these references, no investigations about he structural change of the anode materials during the charge – ischarge process has been carried out [8,24,25].
Herein, the -Fe2O3 nano-ring is synthesized by a facile ydrothermal reaction and then the core-shell -Fe2O3@C nanoing composites are synthesized by hydrothermal reactions of ifferent ratios of glucose and as-prepared -Fe2O3 nano-rings ith further annealing. The as-prepared samples are tested as nodes of LIBs, the core-shell nano-ring electrodes exhibit super lectrochemical performance and the content of carbon shell nfluences the cyclability and rate capability of the anodes.
oreover, the morphology and structure of the anode materials fter cycling are investigated in detail. We found that corehell -Fe2O3@Carbon changed to flower-like networks during ithiation/de-lithiation, which provides faster transport highway or electrons and Li+ via pore walls and pores among the net-
orks. It is the first time to report this evolution phenomenon of -Fe2O3@Carbon during cycling.
. Experimental
.1. Synthesis of samples
Synthesis of -Fe2O3 nano-rings: The sample was synthesized ia a hydrothermal method mediated hydrolysis of FeCl3 with he help of Na2SO4 and NH4H2PO4 [26,28]. That is, 0.6488 g iron hloride (FeCl3), 0.0156 g sodium sulfate (Na2SO4) and 0.0030 g mmonium dihydrogen phosphate (NH4H2PO4) (the molar ratio f three reagents is 40:1:0.25) were dissolved in 200 mL deionzed water by magnetic stirring. The solution was transferred into Teflon-lined autoclave and kept at 220 ◦C for 48 h. The autoclave hen was cooled down to room temperature naturally, the obtained ed precipitate was separated by centrifugation, washed with disilled water and absolute ethanol for three times, and dried in air t 80 ◦C for 12 h. The obtained bare -Fe2O3 nano-ring was labeled s BNR.
Synthesis of core-shell -Fe2O3@C nano-rings composites: 0.2 g s-prepared BNR and 0.6 g (or 0.4 g) glucose were dissolved in 20 mL eionized water by magnetic stirring. The solutions were transerred into Teflon-lined autoclaves and kept at 180 ◦C for 12 h. The ext steps are as the same as those of synthesizing BNR, and then, he dried powders were further calcined at 500 ◦C in a flowing itrogen (N2) atmosphere for 2 h. Finally, core-shell -Fe2O3@C ano-ring composites were obtained and the samples were labeled s CSNR-13%C and CSNR-5%C, respectively. The carbon contents in
-Fe2O3@C composites are about 13 wt% and 5 wt% according to thermal gravimetric analysis (TGA) (see Fig. 1b).
2.2. Materials characterization
Structural characterization of the prepared samples was performed by means of X-ray diffraction (XRD, Model Y2000, China) with Cu K radiation ( = 1.5406 ´̊A) at 30 kV and 20 mA. The morphology and structure of the products were observed using a scanning electron microscope (SEM, Model ZEISS Ultra 55, Germany) and transmission electron microscope (TEM, Model JEM2100HR). The thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) was performed under an air flow of 100 mL min−1 using Du Pont Instruments TGA 2950 from room temperature to 800 ◦C with a heating rate of 10 ◦C min−1.
2.3. Electrochemical measurements
The electrochemical tests were carried out with a CR2032-type coin cell. The materials anode electrodes were fabricated by mixing the active materials with acetylene black (AB) and a binder, poly(vinylidene fluoride) (PVDF), in weight ratios of 6:2:2, in N-methyl-2-pyrrolidone (NMP) solvent. The resultant slurries were uniformly pasted on Cu foil with a blade. These prepared electrode

Y.-H. Sun et al. / Applied Sur
heets were dried at 120 ◦C in a vacuum oven for 10 h. The elecrolyte was prepared by dissolving 1 M LiPF6 in ethylene carbonate EC) and dimethyl carbonate (DMC) with a volumetric ratio of 1:1. he Li metal foil was used as the counter and a reference elecrode. CR2032-type coin cells were assembled in a glove box for lectrochemical characterization. Galvanostatic discharge-charge ycles of cells were performed at room temperature using Neware T-3008-6V1mA-S4 battery cycler (Shenzhen China) in the voltge range of 0.05–3.00 V (vs. Li+/Li) at different current densities. yclic voltammetry (CV) curves were collected at 0.1 mV s−1 within he range of 0.05–3.00 V. In the electrochemical impedance specroscopy (EIS) measurement, the excitation voltage applied to the ells was 5 mV and the frequency range was between 100 kHz and .01 Hz. Both CV and EIS measurements were carried out on an lectrochemistry workstation (CHI660C).
. Results and discussion
.1. Structure and morphology of the samples
The crystalline structure of the samples was investigated by RD and the patterns are shown in Fig. 1a. The samples are ell-crystallized, and all the diffraction peaks can be indexed to
exagonal hematite -Fe2O3 (JCPDS No. 33-0664). There are no dditional diffraction peaks appear in CSNR composites suggestng that the coating of carbon does not change the -Fe2O3 phase. o obvious signals of carbon are observed in the XRD patterns of SNR composites demonstrating the amorphous nature of carbon nd strong diffraction peaks of -Fe2O3 covering up it. The TGA urves in Fig. 1b show the samples have a small weight loss below 00 ◦C due to the removal of surface adsorbed water. Upon 100 ◦C, NR presents a straight line, indicating thermal stability of -Fe2O3 ano-rings, while the composites show an obvious weight loss of round 13 wt% for CSNR-13%C, and 5 wt% for CSNR-5%C between 00 and 400 ◦C, respectively, which is attributed to the combustion f carbon coated on the CSNR composites.
The SEM image in Fig. 2a shows that the prepared -Fe2O3 resents as uniform nano-rings. Based on our previous study 26,28] and the references [29–32], the formation mechanism of he nano-ring is a preferential dissolution process similar to that f hematite nanotubes as follows [28–30]: First, a spindle nanood forms because of the strong adsorption of phosphate ions on aces parallel to the c axis of hexagonal -Fe2O3, and this deter-
ines the nano-rod shape of the -Fe2O3 [28,31]. Second, the acidic ondition results the nano-rods dissolution along the c axis from wo ends to the inner part because the sides are protected by dsorbing many H2PO4− ions, and the dissolution is favored by the ooperative coordination of sulfate and phosphate ions with ferric ons [28–30,32]. We have found that as prolong the hydrothermal ime and increase the temperature, the dissolution of the inner nd the two tips of the nano-rods is drastic, and obtained many horter nano-tubes with larger holes [28]. Thus, phosphate ion is he key factor for the formation of Fe2O3 nano-tube, sulfate ions an accelerate the formation of nano-tube but not the determinng factor. And long hydrothermal time and high temperature are ood for the formation of nano-tube. So, varying the ratios of phoshate and sulfate ion to ferric ion should yield a series of hollow ano-structures, and the references [29,30,32] have proved this iew. In this study, we lower the molar ratio of phosphate ions o Fe3+:SO42−:H2PO42− = 40:1:0.25 (in our previous study [26,28], he molar ratio of Fe3+:SO42−:H2PO42− = 40:1:0.5), and the nanoing Fe2O3 was obtained. With the decrease of phosphate ions, he adsorption of phosphate ions on faces parallel to the c axis of exagonal -Fe2O3 is not enough, and a lot of sulfate ions with relaively strong ability to coordinate Fe3+ ions promote the dissolution
cience 390 (2016) 175–184 177
of the iron oxide nano-rods, and the particles changed from long tubes to short nano-rings. This result is similar to that in references [29,30,32].
After coating by different amounts of carbon generated by glucose, the samples yet keep as nano-ring. In Fig. 2b (CSNR-13%C), several huge carbon spheres co-exist with the nano-rings due to excess glucose forming the isolated carbon spheres. In Fig. 2c (CSNR-13%C) and Fig. 2d (CSNR-5%C), one can find the size of nanorings is different from that of BNR in Fig. 2a. The average length of the nano-rings is increased from 90 nm of BNR to 125 nm of CSNR13%C and 110 nm of CSNR-5%C, and the average outer diameter is increased from around 130 nm of BNR to 150 nm of CSNR-13%C and 140 nm of CSNR-5%C, while the inner diameter is decreased from 60 nm of BNR to 50 nm of CSNR-13%C and 40 nm of CSNR5%C. The length and outer diameter of the core-shell composites are increased and the inner diameter is decreased, which indicates the carbon has coated on the surface of nano-ring -Fe2O3 from inner to outer. Certainly, the size of some nano-rings in Fig. 2c and d are not sure in accordance with the average values mentioned above. The coating fact is further proved by the TEM images and high resolution TEM images in Fig. 2e–h. The TEM images of CSNR5%C in Fig. 2e and f clearly show that a layer of carbon shell perfectly coats on the outer and inner surface of the -Fe2O3 nano-ring, and the thickness of the outer carbon shell is around 4 nm and the inner shell is around 5 nm (Fig. 2f). The high resolution TEM images further prove the coating of carbon on the outer (Fig. 2g) and inner (Fig. 2h) surface of -Fe2O3. There are obvious crystal lattice space of 0.22 nm corresponding to (113) plane (Fig. 2g) and 0.37 nm corresponding to (012) plane (Fig. 2h) of -Fe2O3 crystal, and no lattice in the amorphous carbon shell. The corresponding indexed FFT and inverse FFT patterns after array filter of Fig. 2g and Fig. 2h further prove the coating fact (See Figs. S-2g and h).
3.2. Electrochemical performance
CV curves of the BNR and CSNR-5%C electrodes for the first three cycles in a potential range between 0.05–3.0 V at a scan rate of 0.1 mV s−1 are shown in Fig. 3(a and b). In the first cathodic sweep in Fig. 3a, there are two weak peaks (0.92 and 1.50 V) and a sharp peak (0.72 V). The weak peak at 1.50 V represents the formation of hexagonal -LixFe2O3 by Li-intercalating the -Fe2O3 phase, and the peak at 0.92 V is related to the hexagonal -LixFe2O3 transforming to cubic Li2Fe2O3 [18,20]. The sharp peak at 0.72 V is attributed to the reduction of Fe2+ (Li2Fe2O3) to Fe0 and the formation of amorphous Li2O, as well as, the irreversible reaction with the electrolyte to form a solid electrolyte interface (SEI) film [1,2,16,24,25]. Meanwhile, the anodic process shows two anodic peaks at 1.62 and 1.87 V, indicating two steps of oxidation of Fe (from Fe0 to Fe2+, then from Fe2+ to Fe3+, respectively) [18,24,25,33–36]. During the following two cycles, the sharp peak at 0.72 V in the cathodic sweep disappeared, and the reduction peaks are shifted to 0.82 and 1.3 V, implying the irreversible formation of an SEI film at the first cycle. The electrochemical behaviors of CSNR with different carbon content are similar. Fig. 3b shows the CV performance of CSNR-5%C electrode, which is similar to that of BNR in Fig. 3a. There are one main cathodic peak (0.62 V) and a broad anodic peak (1.74 V) in the first cycle of CSNR-5%C electrode. But the weak cathodic peaks at 1.5 (or 1.3) and 0.92 V in the CV curves of BNR are absent of CSNR5%C, which should be related to the presence of carbon shell’s peak covering up them. The current intensity and the positions of anodic peaks at 1.74 V of the three cycles in this composite electrode are very similar, indicating the good reversibility of the reaction from Fe0 to Fe3+, while for the BNR electrode (Fig. 3a), the current intensity of anodic peaks at 1.62 V decreases gradually and the peaks at 1.87 V almost disappear in the second and third cycles, indicating the poorly reversible reaction from Fe0 to Fe3+ [18,20]. Similarly,

uring the following two cycles, the sharp peaks at 0.62 V in the athodic sweeps disappeared, and the reduction peaks are shifted o 0.82 V, implying the initial irreversible reactions of the elecrode materials are unavoidable, and the subsequent cycles almost verlapped, indicating the good electrochemical reversibility of the SNR electrode. The results indicate that the core-shell nano-ring s beneficial to the lithium insertion and de-insertion in -Fe2O3 hase.
In addition, the initial discharge–charge potential versus capacty profiles of the three samples were carried out in the potential
indow of 0.05–3.0 V (vs. Li+/Li) at a current density of 100 mA g−1. ll the charge-discharge curves of the three samples in Fig. 3c show
, (c) CSNR-13%C composites at high magnification, (d) CSNR-5%C composites; TEM High resolution TEM images of the CSNR-5%C: (g) the outer shell and (h) the inner
similar features to those of nanosized -Fe2O3 reported previously [6,8,9]. The first discharge plateau (slope) of the samples appears at around 1.5 V, which is a feature of lithium reacted with -Fe2O3 to form -LixFe2O3 [8,35,36]. Then, a distinct plateau appeared at approximately 0.80–1.10 V, which could be attributed to the transformation from rhombohedral -LixFe2O3 to cubic Li2Fe2O3 [9,14,36] and then the complete reduction of Fe2+ to metal Fe0. Finally, the voltage gradually decreases to 0.05 V. When the electrode is charged to 3.0 V, a plateau-like potential slope at 1.2–2.25 V was observed which accounts for the oxidation reaction from Fe0 to Fe3+. All these results are consistent with the results of CV measurements. The first discharge and charge capacities are 1450

nd 1070 mAh g−1 for BNR, 1635 and 1180 mAh g−1 for CSNR3%C, 1835 and 1435 mAh g−1 for CSNR-5%C, and with coulombic fficiency of 73.4% (BNR), 72.2% (CSNR-13%C), 78.2% (CSNR-5%C), espectively. The irreversible capacity loss during the first cycle
+
rises due to the extra consumption of Li for the reduction of metal xide to the metal nanoparticles for the formation of SEI and a olymeric layer under deep discharge conditions 0.8–0.05 V vs. i+/Li. According to the theoretical capacity of 1007 mAh g−1 of
cience 390 (2016) 175–184 179
bare nano-rings and 372 mAh g−1 of carbon, the calculated theoretical capacity of the composites based on the carbon content are 975 mAh g−1 of CSNR-5%C and 924 mAh g−1 of CSNR-13%C, respectively. All of the three anodes have the extra initial capacity compared with the theoretical one, which is due to the formation of SEI layer and further lithium storage via interfacial reaction due to charge separation at the metal–Li2O phase boundary [8,9]. The irreversible capacity loss during the first cycle arises due to the extra consumption of Li+ for the reduction of metal oxide to the metal nanoparticles for the formation of SEI and a polymeric layer under deep discharge conditions 0.8–0.05 V vs. Li+/Li. In addition, the solvents present in the electrolyte (EC and DMC) participate in the reaction with Li+ to form the above SEI and polymeric layer.
Fig. 4a shows a comparison of the charge/discharge cycle performance of the BNR and CSNR as anodes of LIBs at the current density of 500 mA g−1 (0.5C). Apparently, the cyclability of CSNR-5%C electrode is dramatically improved compared to those of CSNR-13%C and BNR electrodes. The CSNR-5%C electrode exhibits a high initial charge/discharge capacities of 1220 and 1570 mAh g−1 and rapidly decays to 1120 and 1300 mAh g−1 of the 2nd cycle, the capacity retention rate is high up to 91.8% and 82.8% for charge and discharge process respectively. Then the charge/discharge capacities decay slowly, even enhances a little from the 75th to the 125th cycle and maintain 897 and 920 mAh g−1 until 200 cycles, and the capacity retention rate (relative to the charge/discharge capacities of the 2nd cycle) is high of 80.1% and 70.8% for charge and discharge process respectively. The coulombic efficiency (CE) of the anode increased from 77.7% of the initial cycle to 97.5% of the 200th cycle. Regard to the CSNR-13%C electrode, the capacities rapidly decay from the initial charge/discharge of 820/1160 to 802/880 mAh g−1 of the 2nd cycle, and the capacity retention rate are 97.8% and 75.8%, then gradually decays and keeps stable at 623/630 mAh g−1 from the 50th cycle until to the 200th cycle, with the capacity retention rates (relative to the 2nd cycle) are 77.6% and 71.6%. The CE values of the anode increased from 70.7% of the initial cycle to 98.9% of the 200th cycle. In contrast, the BNR electrode suffers from severe capacity loss at the beginning 30 cycles, from initial charge/discharge capacity of 1102/1470 to the 2nd cycle of 1041/1100 mAh g−1, with the capacity retention rates of 94.5% and 74.8%, and continues decreasing rapidly to 400/410 mAh g−1 of the 40th cycle and then enhances a little to 420/430 mAh g−1 and retains the value until 100 cycles, and the capacity retention rate (relative to the 2nd cycle) is only 40.3% and 38.2%. The CE values of the anode increased from 75.0% of the initial cycle to 97.7% of the 100th cycle. Here, the increase and stabilization of the capacity can be attributed to the ‘formation’ or ‘conditioning’ of the electrode. That means the electrolyte penetrates through the composite (nano-Fe0-amorphous Li2O and SEI film) formed during the first-discharge reaction of Fe2O3 with Li+, as well as, establishes an intimate electrical (electronic) contact of the ‘composite’ also with the Cu current collector. Such ‘formation’ of the electrode needs several charge-discharge cycles. After that, the ‘formation’ of the electrode increases the contact area between active materials and electrolyte and thus yields the increased capacity. Such a phenomena has been noted in oxide anodes like ‘CoO-Li2O’ thin-film composite [37], Fe3O4 [38], Fe2O3 [39,46] and MnCO3 nanoparticles [40]. The above results showed that CSNR electrodes could exhibit improved capacity retention rate and cycling stability compared to BNR electrode, which is in agreement with the CV results in Fig. 3. Here, both the carbon shell and nano-ring -Fe2O3 core play very important role in the superior electrochemical performance. Comparing with the performance of CSNR-13%C electrode, the CSNR-5%C electrode shows higher reversible capacity and longer cycle life. This is attributed to the large effective content of -Fe2O3 in CSNR-5%C, which is responsible for the high

pecific capacity of the electrode because the theoretical capacity f carbon is far below that of Fe2O3. All of the three anodes have arger initial capacity than the theoretical one, and which is due to he formation of SEI layer and further lithium storage via interfaial reaction too [8,9]. The proper content of carbon shell can keep he cycle stability of the electrode by enhancing the conductivity f the electrode materials and providing the restrictions to volme expansion of -Fe2O3 during the discharge/charge processes, nd resulting larger reversible capacity of the composite electrodes.
hile for CSNR-13%C electrode, though larger content carbon shell together with the isolated carbon spheres coexisted) can keep the ycle stability of the electrode (the capacity retention rate of 71.6% ntil 200 cycles, which is a little larger than that of 70.8% of CSNR%C), smaller effective content of -Fe2O3 resulted relative smaller harge-discharge specific capacities of the electrode. Moreover, the bility to charge and discharge Li-ions at higher current density is of normous importance for LIBs in practical use. We have also invesigated the charge-discharge cycle performance of the two CSNR omposite electrodes at 2000 mA g−1 (2C, Fig. 4b) and the rate perormance of the three electrodes with the charge/discharge current ensities increasing from 100 to 5000 mA g−1 (0.1–5C) and then ack to 100 mA g−1, with each current density for 11 cycles (Fig. 4c).
or 200 cycles; (c) rate capability of the electrodes cycled from 100 to 5000 mA g−1 (d) EIS curves of the electrodes before cycling; and (e) the typical equivalent circuit
In Fig. 4b, CSNR-5%C electrode demonstrates high initial chargedischarge capacities of 900 and 1400 mAh g−1 (with a CE of 64.3%) and yet maintains the capacities of 610 and 630 mAh g−1 (with a CE of 97.0%) after 200 cycles, with the capacity retention rate of 70% (relative to the 2nd cycle). While the CSNR-13%C electrode shows charge-discharge capacities of 1050 and 1352 mAh g−1 (with a CE of 77.7%), but only retains 350 mAh g−1 (with a CE of 99.4%) after 200 cycles, the corresponding capacity retention rate (relative to the 2nd cycle) is only 33.3%. In Fig. 4c, the CSNR-5%C electrode still retains capacities of 392/395 mAh g−1 (with a CE of 99.2%) cycled at 5000 mA g−1 and returns to 940/950 mAh g−1 (with a CE of 98.9%) cycled at 100 mA g−1 after 77 cycles at different current densities, which is close to those of CSNR-13%C electrode of 378/380 mAh g−1 (with a CE of 99.5%) cycled at 5C and returns to 780/800 mAh g−1 (with a CE of 97.5%) cycled at 0.1C after 77 cycles, and much higher than those of BNR electrode of 265/280 mAh g−1 (with a CE of 94.6%) cycled at 5C and returns to 620/630 mAh g−1 (with a CE of 98.4%) cycled at 0.1C after 77 cycles. In addition, we noticed that the capacity gap between CSNR-5%C and CSNR-13%C shown in Fig. 4b is bigger than that of cycles at 2C shown in Fig. 4c. This may be related to that the cells were cycled at different current densities and changed frequently in a short time in Fig. 4c, which is harmful

o the capacity stabilization for CSNR-5%C with smaller amount of arbon, and a larger amount of carbon in CSNR-13%C is helpful to etain the capacity under the charging/discharging condition. The imilar phenomenon is observed in other anodes [34,36,41]. It is elieved that the superior electrochemical performances of the two ore-shell composite electrodes should be benefitting from the synrgistic effect of the hollow structure and uniform carbon coating: 1) the inner hole of the nano-ring can offer a larger free space for ccommodating the volume change of -Fe2O3 and buffering the echanical strain formed during repeated volume expansion and ontraction processes; (2) the core-shell nano-rings with a layer of arbon shell on the surface of -Fe2O3 not only can enhance the lectronic conductivity of the electrode by direct contact with - e2O3 particles, which further facilitates electrons and lithium ions
images of BNR after 100 cycles, (b) SEM image of CSNR-13%C, (c and d) SEM images magnifications of CSNR-5%C after 200 cycles at current density of 500 mA g−1, and in this figure legend, the reader is referred to the web version of this article).
transporting throughout the electrode during charge–discharge processes, but also provides a parclose-like effect to restrict the excessive volume change of Fe2O3 and prevent them from aggregation and pulverization during prolonged cycling process. This can be seen from the EIS spectra of the cells before cycling in Fig. 4d and SEM or TEM images of the electrode materials after cycling in Fig. 5. In the EIS spectra (Fig. 4d), the single depressed semicircle in the high-medium frequency range is attributed to the charge transfer process and associated with the capacitance of the interface between electrolyte and electrode. The inclined line in the low frequency region is attributed to the Warburg impedance and associated with the lithium ion diffusion impedance within the electrode materials. The typical equivalent circuit (Fig. 4e) of the electrode was conducted using ZsimpWin software ver. 3.10.

sections.text:
ere, Rs means solution resistance; Rct is the charge transfer resisance and CPEdl is the constant phase element of electric double ayer between the electrolyte and electrode interface; CSEI and RSEI re parallel connection of capacitance and resistance brought by he lithium ion mobility through SEI film formed on the electrode. hese elements are attributed to the semicircle from high to midle frequency range in EIS spectra. ZW is the Warburg impedance elated to the lithium ion diffusion in the anode materials, which s associated with the inclined line in the low frequency. The main tted parameters of each anode were listed in Table 1. From Table 1 nd the enlarged inset image in Fig. 4d, it is apparent that the values f Rs and RSEI of each sample are similar, but the values of Rct and he Warburg admittance coefficient (Y0) are different from each ther. The Rct value of CSNR-5%C (68 ) is much lower than that of he CSNR-13%C (219 ) and BNR electrode (290 ), which indicates hat the CSNR-5%C electrode has lower contact and charge transer resistance and a better electronic conductivity than the others. hough the carbon content attains 13% in CSNR-13%C, the charge ransfer resistance is larger than that of CSNR-5%C. This may be elated to that the isolated huge carbon particles (several microns, ig. 2b) co-existing with the nano-rings, which separated the CSNR articles and decreased the effective surface area between the elecrolyte and the CSNR materials and resulted larger charge transfer esistance of the CSNR-13%C electrode. The Warburg admittance oefficient (Y0) in Table 1 is associated with the lithium ion diffusion n the anode active materials, and the lithium ion diffusion coeffiient (D0) in the solid active particles can be calculated according o the formula (1) [42]:
0 = R2T2
2A2n4F4C20 2
(1)
here R is the gas constant, T is the absolute temperature, A is the urface area of the electrode (here, the diameter of the anode sheet s 12 mm, and the surface area is 1.13 × 10−8 m2), F is the Faraday onstant, C0 is the concentration of Li+ in the electrode (here, the lue of C0 is 1 mol L−1 which is similarly equal to the concentration f the electrolyte.), n is the number of electrons per molecule durng oxidization (the vlue of n is 6 for 1 molecule BNR material, and he mximum 37/6 for 1 molecule CSNR material.), and is Warburg mpedance coefficient (Y0 = 1√2 ). According to the formula (1), the i+ diffusion coefficient of each sample is 3.97 × 10−16 cm2 s−1 for NR, 2.21 × 10−14 cm2 s−1 for CSNR-13%C and 4.51 × 10−14 cm2 s−1 or CSNR-5%C, indicating Li+ diffusion in the core-shell composites s much easier than that in the pure Fe2O3 nanorings. The smaller esistance and faster diffusion of Li+ of CSNR-5%C electrode result n enhanced electrode reaction kinetics and better cycling perfor-
ance of the cells. In order to understand the variation of the electrode materils during lithium-ion insertion and de-insertion, the morphology nd structure of the cycled electrodes after 200 cycles (100 cycles of NR) at a charge/discharge current density of 500 mA g−1 are deterined using SEM and TEM, which are shown in Fig. 5a–h. Fig. 5a nd e are the SEM and TEM images of BNR, it can be seen that most arts of the Fe2O3 nano-rings were destroyed and formed many e2O3 nano-sheets after 100 cycles, which resulted in rapid decay f the capacity. While for the CSNR electrodes after cycling, the ore-shell nano-rings were opened too and formed the nanosheets, nd it is very interested that the nanosheets rebuilt many beautiul flower-like structure fulling of a lot of networks (Fig. 5b, c, d nd f). In Fig. 5b of SEM for CSNR-13%C, there are many isolated arbon spheres co-exist with the flower-like structures, which furher confirmed that the excess carbon didn’t coat on the surface f Fe2O3 in CSNR-13%C composite. We deduced that the formation f flower structure is due to the carbon shell firmly wrapping the racked Fe2O3 nano-sheets and forming the networks, which can be
cience 390 (2016) 175–184
observed from Fig. 5c with low magnification and Fig. 5d with high magnification SEM images of CSNR-5%C. The network can avoid the Fe2O3 to crack again during the cycling process and lower the contact and charge-transfer resistance, and provides faster transport highway for electrons and Li+ via pore walls and pores among the networks. The TEM image of CSNR-5%C in Fig. 5f further proved that the formation of the flower-like networks. Fig. 5g shows the high resolution magnification TEM (HR-TEM) of CSNR-5%C after cycles. It can be seen that there are dark and light colors cross each other.
Fig. 5h shows the enlarged part of the red circle in Fig. 5g, where dark color is composed of many obvious crystal lattices of Fe2O3 and the light color is composed of amorphous carbon. The HRTEM images and the corresponding indexed FFT and inverse FFT patterns after array filter of Fig. 5g further (See Fig. S-5g) proved that the core-shell structure of Fe2O3@C yet exists after cycling, and the Fe2O3 yet keeps crystalline. Even though the rings were opened, the carbon shell yet provides the parclose-like effect and the network structure continue providing sufficient space for the huge volume expansion of Fe2O3 during lithium ion insertion and de-insertion process. Thus the core-shell composite electrodes can exhibit superior rate capability and cycability than those of bare nano-ring -Fe2O3 electrodes. The similar network structure was observed in C60@SnO2 anode after cycling [43], but not observed in Fe2O3@C anode in previous reports.
Besides, we compared the electrochemical performances of the CSNR-5%C in this study with the reported nano-ring Fe2O3 in reference [8], core-shell -Fe2O3@C nano-rings in reference [24], and other Fe2O3/carbonaceous composite anodes, the results were listed in Table 2. The references reported the discharge capacity cycled at 1000 mA g−1, and 861 mAh g−1 of Fe2O3 nanorings was obtained after 100 cycles [8], and 815 mAh g−1 of core-shell -Fe2O3@C was obtained after 160 cycles [24], respectively. Though we didn’t determine the long cycle life of the sample cycled at 1000 mA g−1, we determined the rate capability of the sample cycled at different current densities from 100 to 5000 mA g−1, and then 100 mA g−1 again, and the capacity retains stable at around 830 mAh g−1 after cycled at 1000 mA g−1, together with the capacities cycled at 500 mA g−1 after 200 cycles (920 mAh g−1), 2000 mA g−1 after 200 cycles (630 mAh g−1) and 5000 mA g−1 after 66 cycles (395 mAh g−1), which are sufficient to prove that the core-shell sample (CSNR-5%C) obtained in this study is a promising anode materials for LIBs. Moreover, the cycling performance of CSNR-5C% is higher than those of Fe2O3 nanorods/carbon nanofibers [20], Fe2O3 nanoparticles/C nanocomposites [21], bubble-nanorod Fe2O3/carbon nanofibers [44], porous -Fe2O3 nanorods/carbon nanotubes – graphene foam [45] and 3D Fe2O3/graphene sheets [46]. But, it is admirable that Fe2O3 nanorings in reference [8] show super cyclability and rate capability of 447 mAh g−1 cycled at 10 A g−1 after 1000 cycles, and nanbranches Fe2O3@C nanotubes [36] Exhibit 482 mAh g−1 cycled at 5 A g−1 after 1000 cycles. The huge differences of lithium storage performance of the samples must relate to the morphology, structure, crystal size and specific surface of the Fe2O3, which will influence the electrochemical performance of the electrode, and which need further investigation.
4. Conclusions
In this paper, we reported a core-shell -Fe2O3@C nano-ring composite as anode of LIBs. The -Fe2O3@C nano-rings have been synthesized by a facile hydrothermal reaction of the -Fe2O3 nano-rings with glucose, and following calcination in nitrogen atmosphere. The content of the carbon can be controlled by the ratio of -Fe2O3 nano-rings and glucose. The -Fe2O3@C composite with less carbon content (5%C) as an anode of LIB
Y.-H. Sun et al. / Applied Surface Science 390 (2016) 175–184 183

xhibits superior capacity stability and rate capability compared ith those of the composite with larger carbon content and bare -Fe2O3 nano-ring electrodes. The initial discharge/charge capaciies of 1570/1220 mAh g−1 and retains 920/897 mAh g−1 after 200 ycles at 500 mA g−1. Even cycled at 2000 mA g−1, the initial disharge/charge capacities are still high up to 1400/900 mAh g−1, and eeps 630/610 mAh g−1 after 200 cycles. The excellent lithium ion torage performance is attributed to the carbon shell and nanoing structure in the core-shell -Fe2O3@C composite, which can ncrease the conductivity of the electrode and accelerate the difusion of Li+ in the electrode material, and effectively inhibit the olume change of -Fe2O3 by forming the flower-like networks uring the discharge/charge processes. The core-shell nano-ring nd the formed flower-like network structure after cycling provide uidance for designing excellent anode materials for LIBs.

referenceMentions.context: Rechargeable lithium-ion batteries (LIBs) have been widely used s power sources of different electronic devices due to their high nergy density and long cycling life [1,2].
Rechargeable lithium-ion batteries (LIBs) have been widely used s power sources of different electronic devices due to their high nergy density and long cycling life [1,2].

During the past few ears, the electrochemically active transition metal oxides such as ingle metal oxides Fe2O3, Fe3O4, TiO2, CuO, and Co3O4 [3], and ixed transition-metal oxides including stannates, ferrites, cobalates, and nickelates, have been exploited as anode materials for heir high theoretical capacity and natural abundance [4,5].

During the past few ears, the electrochemically active transition metal oxides such as ingle metal oxides Fe2O3, Fe3O4, TiO2, CuO, and Co3O4 [3], and ixed transition-metal oxides including stannates, ferrites, cobalates, and nickelates, have been exploited as anode materials for heir high theoretical capacity and natural abundance [4,5].

During the past few ears, the electrochemically active transition metal oxides such as ingle metal oxides Fe2O3, Fe3O4, TiO2, CuO, and Co3O4 [3], and ixed transition-metal oxides including stannates, ferrites, cobalates, and nickelates, have been exploited as anode materials for heir high theoretical capacity and natural abundance [4,5].

Among f them, transition metal oxide Fe2O3 has attracted considerable ttention because of its high theoretical capacity (1007 mAh g−1) ompared to graphite (372 mAh g−1), non-toxicity and natural bundance [3].

One way is to design Fe2O3 with different morphologies [6–17] including nanorods [9,13], nano-fibers [10], hollow spheres [11,12], multi-shelled hollow spheres [13,14], nanotubes [8,15,16], nano-rings [8] and mesoporous [17], in which hollow structural materials can enhance the electrochemical performance by the hollow structure minimizing the severe volume change of Fe2O3 during lithium ion insertion and de-insertion.

One way is to design Fe2O3 with different morphologies [6–17] including nanorods [9,13], nano-fibers [10], hollow spheres [11,12], multi-shelled hollow spheres [13,14], nanotubes [8,15,16], nano-rings [8] and mesoporous [17], in which hollow structural materials can enhance the electrochemical performance by the hollow structure minimizing the severe volume change of Fe2O3 during lithium ion insertion and de-insertion.

ecently, Liu reported that nano-ring Fe2O3 anode presents better ithium-storage performance than the counterpart (nano-disk), the apacities are 861 mAh g−1 of Fe2O3 nano-rings and 683 mAh g−1 f Fe2O3 nano-disks cycled at 1000 mA g−1 after 100 cycles; and 47 mAh g−1 of Fe2O3 nano-ring and 157 mAh g−1 of nano-disk ycled at 10 A g−1 after 1000 cycles [8].
Up to now, there are few reports on the lithium-storage erformance of Fe2O3 nano-ring structure [8] and their carbonaeous composites [24,25].
In these references, no investigations about he structural change of the anode materials during the charge – ischarge process has been carried out [8,24,25].

72 V is attributed to the reduction of Fe2+ (Li2Fe2O3) to Fe0 and the formation of amorphous Li2O, as well as, the irreversible reaction with the electrolyte to form a solid electrolyte interface (SEI) film [1,2,16,24,25].

72 V is attributed to the reduction of Fe2+ (Li2Fe2O3) to Fe0 and the formation of amorphous Li2O, as well as, the irreversible reaction with the electrolyte to form a solid electrolyte interface (SEI) film [1,2,16,24,25].
similar features to those of nanosized -Fe2O3 reported previously [6,8,9].

5 V, which is a feature of lithium reacted with -Fe2O3 to form -LixFe2O3 [8,35,36].

All of the three anodes have the extra initial capacity compared with the theoretical one, which is due to the formation of SEI layer and further lithium storage via interfacial reaction due to charge separation at the metal–Li2O phase boundary [8,9].
All of the three anodes have arger initial capacity than the theoretical one, and which is due to he formation of SEI layer and further lithium storage via interfaial reaction too [8,9].

Besides, we compared the electrochemical performances of the CSNR-5%C in this study with the reported nano-ring Fe2O3 in reference [8], core-shell -Fe2O3@C nano-rings in reference [24], and other Fe2O3/carbonaceous composite anodes, the results were listed in Table 2.

The references reported the discharge capacity cycled at 1000 mA g−1, and 861 mAh g−1 of Fe2O3 nanorings was obtained after 100 cycles [8], and 815 mAh g−1 of core-shell -Fe2O3@C was obtained after 160 cycles [24], respectively.

But, it is admirable that Fe2O3 nanorings in reference [8] show super cyclability and rate capability of 447 mAh g−1 cycled at 10 A g−1 after 1000 cycles, and nanbranches Fe2O3@C nanotubes [36] Exhibit 482 mAh g−1 cycled at 5 A g−1 after 1000 cycles.

metadata.abstractText: Core-shell nano-ring -Fe2O3@Carbon (CSNR) composites with different carbon content (CSNR-5%C and CSNR-13%C) are synthesized using a hydrothermal method by controlling different amounts of glucose and -Fe2O3 nano-rings with further annealing. The CSNR electrodes exhibit much improved specific capacity, cycling stability and rate capability compared with that of bare nano-ring -Fe2O3 (BNR), which is attributed to the core-shell nano-ring structure of CSNR. The carbon shell in the inner and outer surface of CSNR composite can increase electron conductivity of the electrode and inhibit the volume change of -Fe2O3 during discharge/charge processes, and the nano-ring structure of CSNR can buffer the volume change too. The CSNR-5%C electrode shows super high initial discharge/charge capacities of 1570/1220 mAh g−1 and retains 920/897 mAh g−1 after 200 cycles at 500 mA g−1 (0.5C). Even at 2000 mA g−1 (2C), the electrode delivers the initial capacities of 1400/900 mAh g−1, and still maintains 630/610 mAh g−1 after 200 cycles. The core-shell nano-rings opened during cycling and rebuilt a new flower-like structure consisting of -Fe2O3@Carbon nano-sheets. The space among the nano-sheet networks can further buffer the volume expansion of -Fe2O3 and facilitate the transportation of electrons and Li+ ions during the charge/discharge processes, which increases the capacity and rate capability of the electrode. It is the first time that the evolution of core-shell -Fe2O3@Carbon changing to flower-like networks during lithiation/de-lithiation has been reported.
metadata.creator: Elsevier
